title: I turned my open-source project into a full-time business
dot:
digraph EmailEngineJourney{rankdir=TB;node[shape=box];Start[label="Started with Open-Source Software
(15 years ago)
- Used permissive licenses (MIT, BSD)
- Aimed for maximum reach"]; Nodemailer[label="Developed Nodemailer
- Major success with many users
- Rejected donations to maintain fairness"]; Reflection[label="Reflected on missed opportunities
- Startup using Nodemailer was acquired
- No compensation received"]; NewStart[label="Started EmailEngine
- Released under AGPL license
- Implemented Contributor License Agreements (CLA)"]; InitialBusinessModel[label="Initial Business Model
- Offered AGPL version and MIT version for subscribers
- Only gained few paying subscribers"]; BusinessPivot[label="Pivoted Business Model
- Redesigned UI
- Introduced license key system
- Changed license from AGPL to commercial"]; Growth[label="Growth in Revenue
- Initial revenue: 750€ in 1.5 years
- First month after pivot: 1750€
- Current MRR: 6100€"]; Regret[label="Regret
- Wish had started selling software earlier
- Selling to businesses more reliable than donations"];Start->Nodemailer;Nodemailer->Reflection;Reflection->NewStart;NewStart->InitialBusinessModel;InitialBusinessModel->BusinessPivot;BusinessPivot->Growth;Growth->Regret;subgraph cluster_notes{label="Key Takeaways";style=dashed;node[shape=ellipse];Note1[label="Open-source can be limiting
if not monetized properly"];Note2[label="CLAs can deter some contributors"];Note3[label="Commercial licensing can lead to
significant revenue growth"];Note4[label="Smaller tools can still promote larger projects"];} Growth->Note1;Growth->Note2;Growth->Note3;Growth->Note4;}
